CODIFIED ORDINANCES OF BARBOURSVILLE
PART SEVEN - BUSINESS AND TAXATION CODE
CHAPTER ONE - Business Regulations
Art.
705. Sales From Motor Vehicles.
Art.
711. Oil and Gas Wells.
Art.
715. Pawnbroker Regulations.
ARTICLE 705
Sales From Motor Vehicles
705.01   License required.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Parking where public safety is threatened - see TRAF.
361.03(a)(17)
Blocking roadway - see TRAF.
361.11
 
 
705.01 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person within the Municipality shall offer for sale, sell or distribute
any food or beverage from a motor vehicle in any Municipal street, sidewalk or
public way without a Municipal license to do so as provided in this article.
   Every person desiring to sell or distribute food or beverages from a motor
vehicle shall make application to the Village Recorder for an annual license to
do so. Upon the filing of applications by persons, the members of Council shall
inquire of such catering service operator as to the location and number of
vehicles to be used, the days of the week that such equipment will be on
Municipal property, the condition of the equipment, the provisions for removing
any refuse that may be created and to ascertain such other facts as would
relate to the public welfare and safety of the residents of the Municipality.
Thereafter, a license shall be issued to the operator of the catering services
only after the affirmative vote of a majority of the members of Council in
attendance at any regular or special meeting. The annual fee to be paid for
such license shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00).
ARTICLE 711
Oil and Gas Wells
711.01   Definitions.
711.02   Drilling without a permit.
711.03   Application for permit.
711.04   Reference of application.
711.05   Application for torpedoing or shooting.
711.06   Action on application.
711.07   Bond required before granting application.
711.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Oil and gas - see W. Va. Code Art. 22B
 
 
711.01 DEFINITIONS.
   "Person", as used in this article includes any individual, firm,
corporation, association or copartnership.
(1941 Code Sec. 17-3-1)
711.02 DRILLING WITHOUT A PERMIT.
   No person shall drill any well for oil or gas, or shoot or torpedo any well,
or use any explosives in connection with the filling or operation of any well,
within the corporate limits of the Municipality or within one mile of the
corporate limits thereof, without first obtaining the permission of Council as
hereinafter provided.
(1941 Code Sec. 17-3-2)
711.03 APPLICATION FOR PERMIT.
   Any person desiring to obtain permission to drill for oil or gas shall,
before actual drilling is begun, file a written application, accompanied by a
filing and inspection fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) with the Village Recorder
at least ten days before such application is acted upon by Council, which
applications shall state the following:
   (a)   The name of the applicant, the person for whom such well is being
drilled, the name of the driller of the well, the owner of the land upon which
the well is to be drilled, and the name of the lessee, if any.
   (b)   The location, as shown upon a blueprint attached to the application,
of the well, its proximity to any street, alley, dwelling house or other
building.
   (c)   The names of all the owners of the property within a radius of 300
feet of the well location, as shown on the blueprint.
   (d)   The nature and character of the machinery and equipment to be used in
the drilling of such well.
   (e)   The streets, alleys, and other ways, if any, necessary to be crossed,
traversed, or used in laying pipeline or lines for transportation and marketing
such oil or gas.
   (f)   That application has been made to the Department of Energy for the
right to drill such well, and that the Department has granted such permit.
   (g)   That the applicant will, if the permit is granted file a bond in the
penalty of ten thousand dollars ($10,000) conditioned that it will indemnify
and save harmless the Municipality from any and all liability by reason of the
drilling, shooting, torpedoing or use of any other explosives in the well, any
excavations or other thing, and by reason of any pipeline or lines, and all
persons whomsoever by reason of any and all injury to person or to property by
reason of the drilling, shooting, use of explosives or otherwise, or by any
pipeline or lines built, laid or constructed and/or operated, and,
   (h)   Any additional information that Council may require.
      (1941 Code Sec. 17-3-3)
711.04 REFERENCE OF APPLICATION.
   Upon the filing of the application, as hereinabove provided, it shall be
immediately referred to a committee of Council to be named by the Mayor and to
be composed of three members, who shall make a complete and thorough
investigation of the advisability of the granting of such permit, and make a
report of their findings to Council.
(1941 Code Sec. 17-3-4)
711.05 APPLICATION FOR TORPEDOING OR SHOOTING.
   Any person desiring to torpedo or shoot any oil or gas well, or use
explosives of any kind or character in connection with the drilling or
operation of such well, shall first make a separate application to Council for
permission to use such explosives, which application shall set forth the kind,
character and amount of the explosives, the location where the same is to be
used, the date and time that such explosives are to be used and the name of the
person using the same.
   Council, upon receiving the application, shall forthwith determine whether
torpeoding or shooting of the well or the use of explosives, set out in the
application, will be safe to persons or property and may grant the applicant a
permit to use the explosives as requested in the application.
   Any and all explosives used pursuant to the provisions of this article shall
be under the direct supervision of the Police Chief.
(1941 Code Sec. 17-3-5)
711.06 ACTION ON APPLICATION.
   Council, in acting upon the application for drilling, shooting or torpedoing
of any well within the Municipality or within one mile of the corporate limits
thereof shall, before the permit is granted, take into consideration the
location of the well, the probable danger of drilling in such location, the
danger to inhabitants and property nearby, and the use of explosives in and
around such well, and may, in their discretion, reject the permit for the
drilling or shooting of such well, if the same would probably become a menace
to the safety and health of the inhabitants and property in the vicinity of
such operation.
(1941 Code Sec. 17-3-6)
711.07 BOND REQUIRED BEFORE GRANTING APPLICATION.
   No permit to drill and/or shoot or torpedo any oil or gas well, as provided
in this article shall be issued until the applicant has filed with Council a
bond in the penalty and conditioned as provided in Section
711.03(g), approved as to form by the Village Attorney, and with surety or
sureties thereon approved by Council.
(1941 Code Sec. 17-3-7)
711.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this article shall be fined not less than
twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than three hundred dollars ($300.00), or
imprisoned not more than thirty days or both.
ARTICLE 715
Pawnbroker Regulations
715.01   Definitions.
715.02   Purchase and pawn transaction records.
715.03   Payment to seller or pledgor.
715.04   Daily report to police by pawnbrokers and secondhand dealers.
715.05   Routine audit and examination of pawn shops.
715.06   Administrative revocation of license.
715.07   Video records of all transactions.
715.08   Standards for new applicants.
715.09   Excess interest prohibited; disclosure requirements.
715.10   Holding period for all pawned or purchased property.
715.11   Identification required.
715.12   Inspection of records.
715.13   Prohibited acts.
715.99   Penalties; enforcement.
715.01  DEFINITIONS.
   (a)    "Pawnbroker" means any person, partnership, association or
corporation, employee or other entity thereof advancing money in a pawn
transaction in exchange for collateral in the property of the pledger.
Pawnbroker does not mean any bank which is regulated by West Virginia law; the
Comptroller of the Currency of the United States; the Federal Deposit Insurance
Corporation; the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System or any other
federal or state authority; and all affiliates thereof and any bank or savings
and loan association whose deposits or accounts are eligible for insurance by
the Bank Insurance Fund or the Savings Association Insurance Fund or other fund
administered by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, all affiliates
thereof, any state or federally chartered credit union, and any finance company
subject to licensing and regulation by West Virginia Division law.
   (b)    "Pawn transaction" means a transaction between a pawnbroker and a
pledgor where the pledger's property is placed in the possession of the
pawnbroker as security for money or other valuable consideration provided to
the pledgor on the condition that the pledgor may pay a pawn charge and redeem
his or her property within a predetermined time frame. Pawn transactions do not
include those transactions where securities, titles or printed evidence of
indebtedness are used as security for the transaction.
   (c)    "Pledgor" means a person who delivers the pledge into the possession
of a pawnbroker.
   (d)    "Purchase" or "purchase transaction" means the transfer and
delivering of goods by a person to a pawnbroker by acquisition for value,
consignment or trade for other goods. This definition does not include
purchases by pawnbrokers of items not used or intended for resale, consignment
or trade of the item to another.
(Ord. 2015-2. Passed 6-4-15.)
715.02 PURCHASE AND PAWN TRANSACTION RECORDS.
   (a)    All pawnbrokers shall make and maintain a transaction report on all
purchase or pawn transactions, except for refinance pawn transactions or
merchandise bought from a manufacturer or wholesaler with an established place
of business. The required transaction report shall include the following:
      (1)    The date of the transaction;
      (2)    The name of the seller;
      (3)    The name of the clerk who handled the transaction;
      (4)    The corresponding pawn ticket number:
      (5)    The terms of the loan or purchase:
      (6)    A copy of the seller's or pledgor's government photo
identification and type; Provided, that if the seller or pledgor does not have
a government issued photo identification, the pawnbroker shall take a
photograph of the seller or pledgor as set forth in Section
 715.11; and
      (7)    A detailed description of the property as set forth in this
section.
   (b)    For purposes of meeting the requirements of subsection (a) of this
section, a detailed description of the property shall include the following:
      (1)   In the case of firearms, the brand, model, caliber, type, and
serial number;
      (2)    In the case of jewelry, the type of jewelry presented, the karat
weight, whether it is made of white gold, yellow gold or other precious metals,
and other description of the stones, shape, cut, and oddities, etc. which are
sufficient to describe the article of jewelry;
      (3)    In the case of other types of articles and property, the type of
article, brand, model and serial number on the article, or any other such
identifying information or description to which is sufficient to specifically
describe the item or property.
   (c)    The seller or pledgor shall be required to sign the pawn transaction
statement or purchase transaction statement; and a signed statement from the
seller or pledgor affirming ownership shall appear on the bill of sale or pawn
ticket that is completed by the seller or pledgor at the time of the
transaction.
   (d)   The pawnbroker shall maintain the original of all purchase or pawn
transaction statements for three years, and shall make the original copies of
the purchase or pawn transaction statements available for inspection by law
enforcement officers and law enforcement agencies upon request during the
posted hours of operation of the business.
   (e)   The information required to be collected pursuant to this section is
confidential, is not public record, and should only be disclosed as provided in
this section or otherwise provided by law: Provided, That the confidential
nature of this information in no way impedes the pawnbroker's duty to
accurately collect and timely provide the information to law enforcement.
(Ord. 2015-2. Passed 6-4-15.)
715.03  PAYMENT TO SELLER OR PLEDGOR.
   All payments made by a licensed pawnbroker to a seller or pledgor of
property shall be made by check mailed to the address of the seller or pledgor.
It shall be a violation of this article for a pawnbroker to make any payment in
cash. (Ord. 2015-2. Passed 6-4-15.)
715.04  DAILY REPORT TO POLICE BY PAWNBROKERS AND SECONDHAND DEALERS.
   (a)    Any person doing business as a pawnbroker or secondhand dealer in
bicycles, jewelry, furs or other personal property, including but not limited
to, televisions, stereos, DVD players, VCRs, amplifiers, cameras, musical
instruments or other personal property, including dealers in old gold, silver,
platinum or other precious or semi-precious metals or precious or semi-precious
stones shall every day before the hours of 12:00 Noon, or by written agreement
with the Chief of Police of the Village or his designees, electronically submit
and upload a true and correct report of all goods, wares, merchandise or things
received on deposit, pledged, or purchased the previous day to a law
enforcement web site designated by the Chief of Police.
    The required information shall be provided to the web site by the
proprietor or his designee and shall include the following information:
      (1)   Date and time when the property was received;
      (2)   Description of the property;
      (3)   Description of the individual from whom the property was received
from a valid state I.D. or other picture I. D., federal I. D. or other picture
I. D. shall be viewed and verified as to picture the individual by the
proprietor or clerk receiving the item (s);
      (4)   Whether the item was purchased, taken as collateral for a loan or
taken on consignment;
      (5)   Current address and telephone number from the individual providing
the property.
   (b)    In the event the Village of Barboursville does not select a law
enforcement web site, or if a selected law enforcement web site is dissolved or
if the Chief of Police elects to discontinue utilizing the law enforcement web
site, all persons doing business as pawnbrokers or second hand dealers shall
continue to submit said information to the Police Department by providing a
written property card. This property card shall contain the identical
information provided in the electronic uploads. The time frame for submission
of pawn information will remain the same.
   (c)    The proprietor or his designee shall have sole discretion as to
receipt of merchandise for sale, trade, collateral or pawn and may refuse
anyone therein services upon the suspicion that they are not the true owners of
any property presented. If at any time an individual presents to the proprietor
or his designee that they are transacting the business for a third party
(owner) or that they have only a partial interest in said property the
proprietor or his designee must refuse to transact any pawn, trade, loan or
commission sale with said individual and report such incident to the Chief of
Police or his designee.
   (d)    A law enforcement officer may at any time during an investigation
require a pawnbroker, proprietor or dealer of second hand consignment goods or
their personal representative to present items for inspection upon demand if
officer has reasonable belief that said items were misappropriated, stolen, or
taken under false pretense may confiscate the items, but must also show within
thirty (30) days to the appropriate judicial authority that there is a
reasonable nexus to the item as evidence of a crime even though the perpetrator
may not be ascertained. Further, upon such determination by the judicial
officer as to the rightful property owner and only by order of the judicial
officer shall the Chief of Police or his designee insure that confiscated lems
are returned per said judicial order.
(Ord. 2015-2. Passed 6-4-15.)
715.05 ROUTINE AUDIT AND EXAMINATION OF PAWN SHOPS.
   In order to assure compliance with this article, the Chief of Police or his/
her designee may conduct a physical audit and examination of a pawn shop not
more than one time a year. If the Police Chief has reasonable cause to believe
that unlawful or fraudulent activity has occurred, either the Police Chief or
his/her designee may audit and examine a pawn shop on a more frequent basis
than one time per year. If it is determined that unlawful or fraudulent
activity has occurred, the City may recover the reasonable cost of
investigating and uncovering the activity.
(Ord. 2015-2. Passed 6-4-15.)
715.06 ADMINISTRATIVE REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   The license of any pawn shop may be administratively revoked if it is
determined by the municipal judge that:
   (a)   The licensee has been convicted of a felony in connection with the
operation of a pawn shop;
   (b)   A licensee knowingly, recklessly or continuously violated this
Article;
   (c)   A fact or condition exists that, if it had existed or had been known
at the time of the original application, would have justified license refusal;
   (d)   The license knowingly submits materially false or misleading documents
with the intent to deceive the Police Department or any other person; or
   (e)   The licensee is unable or ceases to continue to operate the pawnshop.
      (Ord. 2015-2. Passed 6-4-15.)
715.07 VIDEO RECORDS OF ALL TRANSACTIONS.
   Each licensed pawn shop owner shall be required to maintain an operating
video recording system capable of recording each transaction occurring at the
pawn shop. Video recordings shall be made and retained of each such transaction
and stored for not less than 60 days from the date of the transaction. Upon
request from the Police Department, the owner shall provide a copy of
transactions occurring on a date as requested by the Police Department. The
existence of an operating system shall be a requirement of obtaining or
retaining a license to operate a pawn shop and shall apply to all such pawn
shops, whether they were operating prior to the effective date of this section
or not.
(Ord. 2015-2. Passed 6-4-15.)
715.08 STANDARDS FOR NEW APPLICANTS.
   Any original applicant for a license to operate a pawn shop shall establish
that he or she has not previously been convicted of a felony or of any other
criminal offense relating to dishonesty or breach of trust in connection with
the operation of a pawnshop. The issuing authority shall deny the issuance of a
license to operate a pawn shop to anyone having a prior history of conviction
of such offenses. At the request of the issuing authority, the Police
Department shall determine whether an applicant has been convicted of any
offense identified in this section.
(Ord. 2015-2. Passed 6-4-15.)
715.09  EXCESS INTEREST PROHIBITED; DISCLOSURE REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)    It shall be unlawful for any pawnbroker to charge or collect a
greater benefit or percentage upon money advanced, and for the use and
forbearance thereof, than the rate of 3% per month. Nothing in this section
shall be construed so as to conflict with any law pertaining to usury. Any
existing usury laws shall supersede this section.
   (b)    Each pawnbroker, when making a loan under a license issued under this
Article, must disclose in printed form on the pawn contract the following
information to the persons receiving the loan:
      (1)    The amount of money advanced, which must be designated as the
amount financed;
      (2)    The maturity date of the pawn, which must be at least 30 days
after the date of the pawn;
      (3)    The total pawn interest and service charge payable at the maturity
date, which must be designated as the finance charge;
      (4)    The total of payments that must be paid to redeem the pledged
goods on the maturity date, which must be designated as the total of payments;
and
      (5)    The annual percentage rate.
   (c)    Each pawnbroker may contract for and receive a monthly finance charge
including interest and fees not to exceed one-fifth of the loan amount, for
appraising, investigating title, storing and insuring the collateral, closing
the loan, making daily reports to the Police Department, complying with
regulatory requirements and for all other services. Such fees, when made and
collected, shall not be deemed interest for any purpose of law.
(Ord. 2015-2. Passed 6-4-15.)
715.10  HOLDING PERIOD FOR ALL PAWNED OR PURCHASED PROPERTY.
   Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, pawn shop licensees
shall hold all property, whether pawned or purchased, for a minimum period of
30 days prior to any disposition thereof. (Ord. 2015-2. Passed 6-4-15.)
715.11 IDENTIFICATION REQUIRED.
   At the time of each transaction, the pawnbroker shall obtain a photocopy of
the state issued identification of the person involved in the transaction. If
no such identification is available, the pawnbroker shall photograph the person
in color and record the customer's name, residence address, date of birth,
social security number, gender, height and weight and attach the information to
the photograph. (Ord. 2015-2. Passed 6-4-15.)
715.12 INSPECTION OF RECORDS.
   All records of each licensed pawn shop shall be at all times available for
inspection by the Police Department. All records of the pawn shop shall be
maintained for a minimum period of three years. (Ord. 2015-2. Passed 6-4-15.)
715.13  PROHIBITED ACTS.
   (a)    No pawnbroker shall purchase or take any article in pawn or pledge
from any person appearing to be intoxicated.
   (b)     No pawnbroker shall purchase or take any article in pawn or pledge
from any person known to have been convicted of theft. The Police Department
will provide a current list of such criminal convictions to all pawnbrokers
located in the City.
(Ord. 2015-2. Passed 6-4-15.)
715.99  PENALTIES; ENFORCEMENT.
   (a)    The penalty for the first violation of this article shall be not less
than $100.00 nor more than $500.00.
   (b)   The penalty for the second violation of this article shall be not less
than $250.00 nor more than $500.00.
